text.author: Wikipedia
text.title: Jerome
text.summary1: (human1) Saint Jerome (born Eusebius Sophronius Hieronymus) was a 4th-5th Century Latin Catholic priest, confessor, theologian, and historian, known for the Vulgate translation of the Bible into Latin and his teachings on Christian moral life.
text.summary2: (claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) Jerome, a 4th-century Catholic priest, theologian and historian, is primarily known for translating the Bible into Latin (the Vulgate), writing extensive biblical commentaries, and advocating Christian moral life while maintaining close relationships with female ascetics.
text.summary3: (gpt4o; postedited) Saint Jerome, a Latin Catholic priest and prominent theologian born around 347 AD converted after studies in Rome and lived an ascetic life, focusing on theological studies and Hebrew learning, and is renowned for translating the Bible into Latin (the Vulgate) and advocating for Christian moral life, especially for women, through connections with female ascetics.
text.summary4: (Llama-3.2-3B-Instruct; postedited) Jerome, also known as Saint Jerome, was a Latin Catholic priest, confessor, theologian, and historian who was born in Stridon, Dalmatia and lived from approximately 347 to 420 AD, and is best known for his translation of the Bible into Latin, known as the Vulgate, and his commentaries on the Gospels, as well as his teachings on Christian moral life.
text.summary5: (Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct; postedited) Jerome, also known as Saint Jerome, was a Latin Catholic priest and theologian born in Stridon, who became famous for translating much of the Bible into Latin (the Vulgate) and focusing on Christian moral life, particularly that of women.
